column1: Cancún ( or ; Spanish pronunciation: [kaŋˈkun] pronunciation ) is a city in southeast Mexico on the northeast coast of the Yucatán Peninsula in the Mexican state of Quintana Roo. It is a significant tourist destination in Mexico and the seat of the municipality of Benito Juárez. The city is on the Caribbean Sea and is one of Mexico's easternmost points.
Cancún is just north of Mexico's Caribbean coast resort band known as the Riviera Maya. In older English-language documents
column2: the city’s name is sometimes spelled "Cancoon"
column3: an attempt to convey the sound of the name. It is also home to the Clippers who blew a 3-1 lead.

column1: == Etymology and coat of arms ==
There are two possible translations of Cancún
column2: based on the Mayan pronunciation kaan kun. The first translation is "nest of snakes". The second version and less accepted is "place of the golden snake".The shield of the municipality of Benito Juárez
column3: which represents the city of Cancún
column4: was designed by the Mexican-American artist Joe Vera.

column1: It is divided into three parts: the color blue symbolises the Caribbean Sea
column2: the yellow the sand and the red the sun with its rays.

column1: == History ==
As documented in the earliest colonial sources
column2: Cancún was originally known to its Maya inhabitants as Nizuc (Yucatec Maya [niʔ suʔuk]) meaning either "promontory" or "point of grass".  In the years after the Conquest
column3: much of the Maya population died off or left as a result of disease
column7: leaving only small settlements on Isla Mujeres and Cozumel Island.The name Cancún
column8: Cancum or Cankun first appears on 18th-century maps. The meaning of Cancún is unknown
column9: and it is also unknown whether the name is of Maya origin. If it is of Maya origin
column10: possible translations include "Place/Seat/Throne of the Snake" or "Enchanted Snake". Snake iconography was prevalent at the pre-Columbian site of Nizuc.When development of the area as a resort was started on January 23
column12: Isla Cancún had only three residents
column13: all caretakers of the coconut plantation of Don José de Jesús Lima Gutiérrez
column14: who lived on Isla Mujeres. Some 117 people lived in nearby Puerto Juárez
column15: a fishing village and military base.

column1: Due to the reluctance of investors to gamble on an unknown area
column2: the Mexican federal government financed the first nine hotels. The first financed hotel was a Hyatt
column3: Cancún Caribe
column4: but the first hotel built was the Playa Blanca
column5: which later became a Blue Bay hotel. It is now named Temptation Resort. At the time it was an elite destination
column6: famous for its virgin white sand beaches.

column1: The city began as a tourism project in 1974 as an Integrally Planned Center
column2: a pioneer of FONATUR (Fondo Nacional de Fomento al Turismo
column3: National Fund for Tourism Development)
column4: formerly known as INFRATUR. Since then
column5: it has undergone a comprehensive transformation from being a fisherman's island surrounded by virgin forest and undiscovered shores to being one of the two most well-known Mexican resorts
column6: along with Acapulco. The World Tourism Organization (WTO)
column8: awarded the Best of the Best award "for excellence and good governance" to the Trust for Tourism Promotion of Cancún on February 3
column9: 2007. This award ensured Cancún the ongoing support of the Department of Education and Knowledge Management of the WTO.

column1: Most 'Cancunenses' are from Yucatán and other Mexican states. A growing number are from the rest of the Americas and Europe. The municipal authorities have struggled to provide public services for the constant influx of people
column2: as well as limiting squatters and irregular developments
column3: which now occupy an estimated ten to fifteen percent of the mainland area on the fringes of the city.

column1: == City layout ==
Apart from the island tourist zone (part of the world's second-longest coral reef)
column2: the Mexican residential section of the city
column3: the downtown part of which is known as "El Centro"
column4: follows a master plan that consists of "supermanzanas" (superblocks)
column7: non-residential area cut in by u-shaped residential streets.

column1: Ave. Tulum is the main north-south artery
column2: connecting downtown to the airport
column3: which is some 30 km (19 mi) south of downtown. Tulum is bisected by Ave. Cobá. East of Ave. Tulum
column4: Cobá becomes Ave. Kukulcan which serves as the primary road through the 7-shaped hotel zone. Ave. Tulum ends on the north side at Ave. Paseo José López Portillo which connects to the main highway west to Chichén Itzá and Mérida. Another major north-south road is Ave. Bonampak which runs roughly parallel to Ave. Tulum. The main ferry to Isla Mujeres is located in Puerto Juárez
column5: on Ave. Paseo José López Portillo.

column1: Cancún's mainland or downtown area has diverged from the original plan; development is scattered around the city. The remaining undeveloped beach and lagoon front areas outside the hotel zone are now under varying stages of development
column2: in Punta Sam and Puerto Juarez to the north
column3: continuing along Bonampak and south toward the airport along Boulevard Donaldo Colosio. One development abutting the hotel zone is Puerto Cancún; also Malecon Cancún is another large development.

column1: == Cancún Airport's old Control Tower Memorial ==
Despite being a young city
column2: Cancún has a memorial monument of its foundation on a replica of the old Airport Control Tower that resembles to its own date of foundation. The original control tower was a provisional wooden structure to satisfy the operative needs of the recently created airport. Some documents of the city mention that in that time there were no other formal buildings constructed in the city
column3: being possibly the first built structure of Cancún's recent history.The old airport was located on the same part of the city that today corresponds to the Kabah Avenue. The tower is 15 meters tall
column5: and has a base dimension of 5 × 5 meters. The memorial was first built in 2002
column8: but the structure was damaged after Hurricane Wilma in 2005. After the claims of the local people asking to rebuild the tower memorial
column9: a new version was built on 2010
column10: which was later abandoned without proper maintenance until Woox Pinturas
column12: made a donation to restore the structure to its original appearance.

column1: == Maya archaeological sites ==
There are some small Mayan vestiges of the pre-Columbian Maya civilization in Cancún. El Rey (Las Ruinas del Rey) is located in the Hotel Zone. El Meco
column2: a more substantial site
column3: is found on the mainland just outside the city limits on the road north to Punta Sam.Close by in the Riviera Maya and the Grand Costa Maya
column4: there are sites such as Cobá and Muyil (Riviera) the small Polé (now Xcaret)
column11: in the south of the state. Chichén Itzá is in the neighboring state of Yucatán.

column1: == Transportation ==
Cancún is served by the Cancún International Airport with an added main runway that commenced operation as of October 2009. It has many flights to North America
column2: Central America
column3: South America
column4: and Europe. It is located on the northeast of the Yucatán Peninsula serving an average of about fifteen million passengers per year. The airport is located around 20 km (12 mi) from the hotel zone
column5: approximately a 20 minute trip by car.

column1: The island of Isla Mujeres is located off the coast and is accessible by ferry from Puerto Juárez and Playa Tortugas in the Hotel Zone.
Cancún is also served by three private bus lines that connect it to the downtown area and the "hotel zone" as well as more distant destinations such as Playa del Carmen and Tulum.
== Climate ==
Cancún has a tropical climate
column2: specifically a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen Aw)
column3: with little difference between seasons
column4: but pronounced rainy and dry seasons. The city is hot year-round
column5: and moderated by onshore trade winds
column6: with an annual mean temperature of 27.1 °C (80.8 °F). Unlike inland areas of the Yucatán Peninsula
column7: sea breezes restrict high temperatures from reaching 36 °C (97 °F) on most afternoons. Annual rainfall is around 1

column1: The rainy season runs from May through late October
column2: when hot temperatures
column3: high humidity
column5: but intense summer thundershowers are common. The dry season normally begins in December and runs through April
column6: when more temperate conditions occur as the northeast trade winds bring northerly breezes
column8: and relative humidity is lowest. The hotel zone juts into the Caribbean Sea
column9: it is surrounded by ocean therefore daytime temperatures are around 1-2 °C less and windspeeds are higher than at the airport located some distance inland
column10: which is the official meteorological station for Cancún
column11: averages as shown below.Thanks to the Yucatán current continually bringing warm water from further south
column12: the sea temperature is always very warm
column13: with lows of 79 °F (26 °C) in winter and highs of 84 °F (29 °C) in summer.

column1: === Tropical storms and hurricanes ===
The tropical storm season lasts from May to December
column2: the rainy season extends into January with peak precipitation in October. February to early May tend to be drier with only occasional scattered showers. Cancún is located in one of the main Caribbean hurricane impact areas. Although large hurricanes are rare
column3: they have struck near to Cancún in recent years
column4: Hurricane Wilma in 2005 being the largest. Hurricane Gilbert made a devastating direct hit on Cancún in September 1988 and the tourist hotels needed to be rebuilt. In both cases
column6: state and municipal authorities were well prepared to deal with most of the effects on tourists and local residents. Hurricane Dean in 2007 also made its mark on the city of Cancún.

column1: 1988's Hurricane Gilbert was the second most intense hurricane ever observed in the Atlantic basin. It landed on the Yucatán peninsula after crossing over the island of Cozumel. In the Cancún region
column2: a loss of $87 million (1989 USD) due to a decline in tourism was estimated for the months October
column3: November and December in 1988.On October 21
column5: Hurricane Wilma made landfall on Mexico's Yucatán Peninsula as a powerful Category 4 hurricane
column6: with strong winds in excess of 150 mph (240 km/h). The hurricane's eye first passed over the island of Cozumel
column7: and then made an official landfall near Playa del Carmen in the state of Quintana Roo at around 11 p.m. local time on October 21 with winds near 140 mph (230 km/h). Portions of the island of Cozumel experienced the calm eye of Wilma for several hours with some blue skies and sunshine visible at times. The eye slowly drifted northward
column8: with the center passing just to the west of Cancún

column1: Two years later after Hurricane Wilma
column3: Hurricane Dean made landfall as a Category 5 storm in Majahual
column4: 190 miles (310 km) to the south of Cancún. Fierce winds at the edge of Dean's impact cone stripped sand off 7.5 miles (12.1 km) of beaches from Punta Cancún (Camino Real Hotel) to Punta Nizuc (Club Med).

column1: The authorities asked tourism operators to suspend sending tourists to Cancún while Hurricane Dean was approaching
column2: but did ask airlines to send empty planes
column3: which were then used to evacuate tourists already there.

column1: == Education ==
Although Cancún is better known as a travel and tourism destination
column2: some colleges and universities offer higher education to both Mexican and foreign students. Private schools in Cancún include Centro Educativo Monteverde
column3: International American School of Cancun

column1: == Sports ==
The city has been home to Atlante F.C.
column2: a traditional Mexico City football club
column3: since 2007. Atlante F.C. was moved to Cancún's Andrés Quintana Roo Stadium when that stadium opened. Its games had low attendance at its previous stadium
column5: which it had been renting.  The team currently plays in the Ascenso MX
column6: the second level of the Mexican football pyramid. The city is also home to the Pioneros de Cancún
column7: who play in the third division Liga Premier de México.

column1: The city is also home to the baseball team Tigres de Quintana Roo
column2: who play in the Mexican League (LMB).

column1: == Drug trafficking network ==
The city has been devastated by violent acts related to drug trafficking. Between 2013 and 2016 there were 76 murders: 31 in 2016
column2: and at least 193 in 2017
column3: the vast majority related to drug trafficking. Most have occurred in the urban nucleus
column4: and there have been various violent episodes with firearms in the so-called "Zona Hotelera". Beginning in 2018 with a high wave of violence
column5: Cancún is above the national average in homicides. In January 2018 alone there were 33 homicides
column6: triple the number from January 2017.The violent acts have begun to put pressure on the tourism industry
column8: Cancún saw its first decrease in international passengers in seven years.In the 21st century
column9: Cancún had largely avoided the bloodshed associated with the trade of illegal drugs
column10: but is known for its retail drug sales to tourists as well as for being a center of money laundering.

column1: The links with Cancún date from the 1990s and early 2000s
column2: when the area was controlled by the Juárez and Gulf drug cartels. In recent years Los Zetas
column3: a group that broke away from the Gulf Cartel
column4: has taken control of many smuggling routes through the Yucatán
column5: according to the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration.
